Does every regular graph of degree $4$ contain a regular subgraph of degree $3$? Is there any $r$ such that every regular graph of degree $r$ must contain a regular subgraph of degree $3$?



A problem of Berge (or Berge and Sauer). Alon, Friedland, and Kalai \cite{AFK84} proved that every $4$-regular graph plus an edge contains a $3$-regular subgraph, and hence in particular every $r$-regular graph with $r\geq 5$ contains a $3$-regular subgraph.

The answer is yes, proved by Tashkinov \cite{Ta82}.





References


[AFK84] Alon, N. and Friedland, S. and Kalai, G., Every {$4$}-regular graph plus an edge contains a
{$3$}-regular subgraph. J. Combin. Theory Ser. B (1984), 92-93.

[Ta82] Tashkinov, Regular subgraphs of regular graphs. Soviet Math. Dokl. (1982), 37-38.
